text: West Mosul for three years this was the
so-called Islamic states capital in Iraq
now it's the broken heart of the
Caliphate the Isis reign of terror is
now over but this is what liberation
looks like the city has been flattened
turned into a graveyard after constant
bombardment and shelling an eerie
silence now hangs over Mosul hundreds of
thousands have been displaced their
lives like their city lies in ruins no
wall has returned to her neighborhood
with her two children for the first time
in a month they've attempted to get away
during the battle but were captured by
Isis soldiers and imprisoned her husband
was shot dead and if I don't the lack of
Harlech Noir says she may now be
liberated but it means nothing without
her husband life she says has become
even more difficult the people of Mosul
are still paying the price for their
freedom at the local hospital there is
chaos
every day people queue up the injured
the sick and the traumatized the battle
is officially over but it's not safe in
Mosul Isis red houses and buildings with
booby traps
returning home now could still mean
death all over the city there are
unexploded devices and it's now up to
the Iraqi military to clean it up there
was a car bomb over there
today we detonated it there where I D is
nearby
there are also IEDs in the school so we
are moving forward because there are
more unexploded device over there all
over this city now Iraqi forces are
working day and night to clear the areas
up from unexploded devices and booby
traps so that families can return to
their homes this particular unit has
been working for the last two days to
get rid of everything the task of
rebuilding the city is monumental but
reconstruction will be easy compared to
building trust real reconciliation will
be a battle thousands of fighters for
the Caliphate have been killed but the
ideology hasn't died with them and who's
to blame for the devastation of Mosul
Sharon was seen Alma Hori says he's
Sunni tribe didn't support Isis but when
the Iraqi military fled the city they
had no choice the Iraqi military control
all of Mosul but when Isis came they ran
we had no weapons to fight them he now
has a stark warning for Baghdad and the
world
I blame what happened to our city on
politics and the leaders the people of
Mosul remain the same politicians need
to strike a deal if they don't come up
with an agreement it will be victims
again laughter is once again allowed in
rural and children leap to take
advantage of their new freedom many have
known nothing but life under Isis the
Iraq they'll inherit has arguably never
been more divided and this generation
will be tested again and again as old
scars in this country often become fresh
wounds gelda Hakim BBC News West Mosul
